app.faq.access-to-publications: How are the types of access to publications determined?
app.faq.access-to-publications.definitio: The barometer uses the UnPaywall Detection Service. If access is open, three types of access are distinguished depending on whether access to full text is done directly from the publisher, on an open archive or both.
app.faq.baro-buzz-lightyear: Does the barometer go beyond open access to publications?
app.faq.baro-buzz-lightyear.definition: For the moment the barometer concerns only open access to publications. The expansion of the perimeter to other types of objects (including research and software data) is under study.
app.faq.date-update.definition: The barometer will be updated every year. Each time, all the data is updated: both the perimeter of the publications and the type of access (closed / open). Indeed, a wave of discount to another, new DOI may appear, including history, thus modifying the scope of publications taken into account. In addition, a publication hitherto in closed access can go into open access, thus modifying the open access rate, including previous years. Thus, in trend, the measurement of the open access rate for the most recent year will be lower than for the previous years because open access can be done in a deferred way over time.
app.faq.difference-ce: What are the differences with the Open Science Monitor of the European Commission?
app.faq.difference-ce.definition:
The European Commission has published the Open Science Monitor whose design and production have been subcontracted to a consortium of CWTS, Esade and Lisbon Council by associating Elsevier as subcontractor. . The Commission's tool uses the Web of Science and Scopus business databases to define the publication field, as well as their affiliate (country) and disciplinary field. In the case of the French barometer, the perimeter is different (French affiliations only). The methodology developed by the French barometer is not commercially dependent, and is completely open (open code and resulting data in Open Data) .Ini, the European tool is based on the owner metadata of commercial bases. On the other hand, the French barometer has set up a transparent methodology to enrich open meta-data.

As a result, these differences in methodological choices result in difference in the results:

  • on the scope of the perimeter for France: envion 270,000 publications over 9 years in the European tool compared to about 860,000 publications over 6 years in the French tool.
  • the Disciplinary declination in each tool is different (10 disciplines in the French barometer against 39 thematic in the European Monitor).
app.faq.methodology-steps: What are the steps of the barometer methodology?
app.faq.methodology-steps.definition:
The methodology put in place is divided into three steps:
  1. Identification of publications with a French affiliation Data on scientific publications come from the source UNPAYWALL , a bibliographic data aggregator (including Crossref service). More than 100 million doi are identified. The available meta-data are analyzed (author and in a small percentage case affiliation) to determine whether the publication is likely to have a French affiliation. With regard to the author's meta-data, a comparison is carried out with the authors having (had) a French affiliation and present in the open databases theses.fr, Pascal and Francis of the CNRS, HAL, and Orcid in particular. If yes, an automatic exploitation of public information on the web with redirection must be set up to confirm or invalidate the presence of a French affiliation. This approach allows, with a good level of certainty (only 4% of the publications considered French are mistakenly), to identify among all global publications, publications associated with authors affiliated with institutions located in France ( Public or private).
  2. Enrichment of identified publications metadata A supervised learning model has been trained on the Pascal and Francis bibliographic basis of the CNRS. Its purpose is to infer the disciplinary field of each publication from its title. In case of inference too uncertain, the disciplinary field retained for the publication is deducted from the Release Review.
  3. Detection of the type of access to publications The barometer uses the service Unpaywall Detection. It regularly combines more than 50,000 sources to detect open access publications.
app.faq.perimeter-barometer: What is the perimeter of the barometer?
app.faq.perimeter-barometer.definition: The barometer examines the type of access to scientific publications, at least one author has a French affiliation, and restricts publications with DOI, including the year of publication is subsequent to 2013.
app.footer.description: The French barometer of open science. Measure the evolution of open access to publications in France from reliable, open and controlled data

app.glossary.acces-ouvert.definition: Open access publications designate research publications made available freely on the public Internet.
app.glossary.apc.definition: Some open-access journals are asking for authors of the publication fees, also called APC (Article Processing charges) to finance the editorial work. There are other financing models.
app.glossary.archive-ouverte.definition: An open archive is a digital platform containing documents from scientific research and offering free, immediate and permanent access to the search results, which everyone can use, download and distribute. The deposit in an open archive is one of the modalities for implementing open access to publications.
app.glossary.clinicaltrials-gov.definiti: Clinicaltrials.gov is the largest register online clinical desiring. It is held by the United States National Library of Medicine on behalf of the National Institutes of Health (NIH).
app.glossary.complete: All definitions in the complete glossary
app.glossary.definition.hal: French national open archive carried by the Center for Direct Scientific Communication (CCSD), mixed service unit. <cta>Hal.com</cta>
app.glossary.diamond.definition: The majority of open access journals do not require publication fees to the authors. In this open access model, publishing costs are taken over upstream by a state, university, a consortium of public institutions or a non-profit organization.
app.glossary.doaj.definition: The Directory of Open Access Journals (DOAJ) is a website that hosts a list of open access journals, established by the Community and managed by Infrastructure Services for Open Access (IS4OA).
app.glossary.doi.definition: Further numbers, letters and symbols, constituting an identifier attributed to a publication, non-ambiguous and sustainable.
app.glossary.essai-clinique.definition: Also called interventional studies, it is a type of clinical research in which participants are distributed in groups receiving one or more interventions so that researchers can evaluate the effects of interventions on biomedical outcomes or health-related results. The notion of intervention is defined as any act carried out on the person not justified by the medical care of the person.
app.glossary.etude-observationelle.defin: These non-interventional studies can be targeted descriptive or etiological. The researcher will observe the reality without intervening on the conditions of exposure of the subjects.
app.glossary.eudract: EudraCT (European Union Drug Regulating Authorities Clinical Trials)
app.glossary.eudract.definition: Eudract is the European database of clinical trials experimental drugs with at least one site in the European Union and starting on 1 May 2004 or after.
app.glossary.gold-full-apc.definition: Relates journals fully open access and free license, systematically asking for publication fees.
app.glossary.openapc.definition: The OpenAPC collects and disseminates open data on the publication costs of certain publications.
app.glossary.pgo.definition: Organization with 75 countries and hundreds of civil society organizations for the transparency of public action.
app.glossary.promoteur.definition: Natural or legal person who is responsible for research involving the human person, manages and verify that his funding is planned.
app.glossary.publication-fr.definition: Publication, at least one author has a French affiliation.
app.glossary.publication.definition: Scientific communication that researchers do their work. These publications have undergone a peer scientific assessment.
app.glossary.resultat-essai-clinique.def: Structured data resulting from a clinical trial. This data can be submitted and made public on a register as clinicaltrials.org.
app.glossary.hybrid.definition: It is considered a hybrid a review that is distributed by subscription and which proposes to its authors to pay a publication fee (also called "APC") so that their article is published in open access. This additional fee payment in a subscription journal establishes a double payment ("Double-Dipping").
app.glossary.title: Glossary of the page
app.glossary.type-hebergement-oa.definit: There are a number of variants for open access to publications. A publication may be open access according to one or more of these variants. Some variations are based on the Economic Model of the publisher or publishing platform that itself puts the open access publication: it is an accommodation in the publisher; Another variant is based on the deposit on one or more open archives: it is then an open archive accommodation.
app.glossary.unpaywall.definition: Global, open database, with more than 100 million must with their available meta-data (title, author, publisher ...) and their access type.

app.health-publi.general.dynamique-ouver: For each year of observation, the barometer estimates the open access level of the entire corpus of French publications (year of publication between 2013 and 2020). Each line on this graph represents the opening level for a year of observation. The progression of the opening between the observation dates (thus from one line to another) also holds the process of liberation of the most recent publications by the expiry of the mobile barriers or the deposits on archives after a period of embargo. Thus, between the observation of {a} and that of {b}, publications published in {c} have won {d} additional points opening (passing from {e}% to {f}%). At the same time, publications published in {G} have progressed {h} opening point (passing from {i}% to {j}%), after a progression of {k} points between the observation of { } and that of {m}. An opening rate of the most recent publications exceeding that of the other demonstrates shorter deadlines in the provision in open access, regardless of the modality of openness.
Evolution of the proportion of open access for health publications by date of observation

open access rate observed in {series.name} ({point.bsoDomain})
{point.y:.2f}% published French publications in {point.publicationDate}
are open access ({point.y_abs} / {point.y_tot})

For each year of observation since 2018, the barometer estimates the proportion of French publications (with at least one French affiliation) in open access. This chart synthesizes the health outcomes for publications published during the year preceding the year of observation. Thus, {a}% of the French health publications published in {b} were in open access the following year, in {C} ({d}).

app.note.flash.edition.2020: According to the 2020 edition of the open science barometer (BSO), 56% of the 156,000 French scientific publications published in 2019 are in open access in December 2020. The rate observed in December 2019, relating to the publications carried out in 2018, N ' was only 49%. The rate increased by 7 points in one year. From one discipline to another, the proportion of open access varies greatly from 75% for mathematics publications at 40% in engineering sciences. In addition, scientific publications published in 2018 or in previous years have an increasing openness rate over time. In particular, those published in 2018 are now open to 54% (+5 points compared to December 2019), and the rise, which concerns all the disciplines, is stronger in those less open.
